answers.answer: Interesting question.That's a lot of phenergan.  I'd probably try to get by with 25mg every 6-8 hours if I could.   Just to minimize any drug intake.

Well its mainly the gastroparesis.  My stomach is paralized.  I can eat food and throw it up later and it would look the same.  The vegas nerve in the stomach that causes it to contact to digest food its damaged.  I am constantly nauseated, vomitting, and in pain.  I have had feeding tubes and I have a gastric pacer.  It helps cause I use to vomit 16-17 times a day and now I may only vomit 5-6 times a day, even when I'm not pregnant.  So thats why I have such a large dose.  I've also built up a tolerance to it.
Pregnancy is probably a minimal cause.  What happened that created the gastroparesis between the 1st and subsequent pregnancies?

Dunno?  Usually gastroparesis is usually associated with people who have diabetes, but I don't have that.  So mine is ideopathic gastroparesis.  I could have been pregnancy its self.  Or sometimes a virus.  Bad drinking water.  They have a lot of theories, but no answers.  It took them 2 years to be able to diagnose me correctly.  I spent lots of time in the hospital and they didn't know what was wrong with me.  Finally they thought the best thing for me would be feeding tubes.  When they went in to place the tubes they also did a full stomach thickness biopsy.  From the biopsy they were able to tell me that the vegas nerve damged and thats why I couldn't keep food down.  I was just happy to finally have a name for it and not think I was crazy.  So who knows?

question: I have nausea caused by two diffrent sources: (1) pregnancy and (2) gastroparesis.  I take 50 mg of phengeran every 4-6 hrs prn nausea.  I took it during my first pregnancy, but I didn't have the gastroparesis then so I didn't have to take it as often as I do now.  I've heard its pretty safe, but I wanted to know if anyone else was or is on it and how they are doing?  Thanks in advance!
title: Is anyone else on phengeran or promethazine?
